summary: The text discusses a message about the 'day of the Lord's vengeance,' emphasizing the repetition of this theme as a form of consolation for a suffering brother. It refers to Edom facing both specific retribution from the Romans and universal judgment on Judgment Day. The message implies that actions will be reciprocated according to one's merits, as indicated by the saying, 'As you have done, it will be done to you,' highlighting the idea of divine retribution.
